wrote:

> *@sb2nov* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In sdks/python/apache_beam/io/filesystem.py
> <https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2136#discussion_r103831143>:
>
> > +
> +  @staticmethod
> +  def match(path, limit=None):
> +    raise NotImplementedError("Filesystem is an abstract class")
> +
> +  @staticmethod
> +  def create(path, limit=None):
> +    raise NotImplementedError("Filesystem is an abstract class")
> +
> +  @staticmethod
> +  def open(path, mode, mime_type='application/octet-stream',
> +           compression_type=CompressionTypes.AUTO):
> +    raise NotImplementedError("Filesystem is an abstract class")
> +
> +  @staticmethod
> +  def open(file_handle):
>
> It was a typo and should have been named close.
>

Tests? Or should we remove this object and make promises about methods the
filehandle has (such as close, write, read, ???).
LGTM
Could you do a rebase?

cc: @katsiapis

Rebased on top of master.
@amitsela PTAL

I believe the proposal was that to find the start of a record you could
scan looking for

uint64 length
uint32 masked_crc32_of_length

and then when you got a match (1/2^32 false positive) you could also check
the data and its CRC (lowering false positive of both to 1/2^64).

The place this falls apart is if your tfrecords might contain nested
tfrecords.

Dan

https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_MavenInstall/8041/
--none--

Re: general approach.

I see two improvements:

1. Providing a simple, uniform way to name shaded artifacts by establishing a central rewritten `artifactId`. This is succeeding where #744 failed!
2. Providing a centralized way to ensure that Guava is not on the public API surface of any module.

I see two downsides:

1. Extra executions for modules that don't depend on Guava. This will slow the build.
2. Modules that need to shade more than just Guava will have to override the shading config. They may actually get it wrong after that, so Guava might still be exposed. -- Thus, while this reduces the amount of config necessary in common cases, does guarantee solution.

I would probably:
* move the shading config back into individual modules. build perf + accuracy. But use the new `artifactId` trick to make the config more uniform.
* find a better way to actually verify that the final output artifacts don't expose Guava. (out of scope for this PR.) This is in-line with prior PR comments.

In otherwords, I would probably take improvement 1, but not 2. 1 is a clear win, but 2 has some drawbacks and doesn't quite guarantee success to justify those drawbacks IMO.
Another good opinion to get would be @davorbonaci .

R: @robertwb @chamikaramj @peihe PTAL

Looks like delete(), copy(), rename() ignore file not found exception.
However, Java is moving away from it.
In Java, delete(), copy(), rename() always throw when file is not found.
Caller can configure whether to throw in the utility class. If callers want to ignore missing files, the utility class will call do a bulk match() and filter out files that are not found.

Then, this brings up the question of the return value of match(). In this PR, the return value is metadata. I didn't see the support for bulk match() and checking which files exist.

R: @amitsela
LGTM

I suppose the ultimate goal would be to merge this and HdfsIO (if technicallly possible). But probably this would be a job to do after merging this PR to avoid adding more noise, so I agree with having the classes into 'inputformat' for the moment.

Thanks again @diptikul for your contribution and I hope you won't be annoyed about doing some of these extra 'aesthetic' changes.

Just to clarify this a bit, `@NeedsRunner` is used by the `TestPipeline` to decide whether to activate the abandoned node detection, not whether to run the pipeline.

I think it boils down to `@NeedsRunner`/`@RunnableOnService` being a bit confusing outside the context of the sdk modules, which brings us back to the question of whether they should or should not be used outside of the `beam-sdks-java-core / beam-runners-core-java` modules. 

I believe that the `TestPipeline` can be adjusted to either.

Since the three changes were trivial, and I've been the bottleneck, I went ahead and implemented them in the merge process. Thanks @tedyu -- this is awesome.

Thanks @iemejia for dramatically improving over my review.
Refactoring according to Aviem's comments. However, `StorageLevelTest` is broken. I'm investigating.
